questions.answerB: At the speed you would travel during the day under similar conditions.
questions.answerC: Faster than you would during the day under similar conditions.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder of the road so other vehicles can see you.
questions.explanation: When riding at night, travel at a slower speed than you would during the day under similar weather and traffic conditions. It can be difficult to see potential hazards in the dark, so slowing down can increase your chances of avoiding any hazards.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat while you are riding and you must stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both brakes and stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Shift your weight toward the good tire.
questions.answerC: Brake on the good tire and steer to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Relax on the handgrips.
questions.explanation: If either of your tires go flat while you are riding, hold the handgrips firmly, ease off the throttle, and maintain a straight course. If you need to brake, gradually apply the brake to the tire that is not flat. As you slow down, edge to the side of the road, squeeze the clutch, and stop.

questions.question: An integrated braking system:
questions.answerA: Applies partial rear braking when the front brake is applied.
questions.answerB: Applies partial front braking when the rear brake is applied.
questions.answerC: Applies even braking for both the front and rear brakes when either is applied.
questions.answerD: Learns and remembers the approximate braking force used by the rider.
questions.explanation: An integrated braking system is a variant of a linked braking system. Partial front braking is applied whenever the rear brake is activated. Check your owner's manual for a detailed explanation of the braking system on your motorcycle.

questions.question: To stop quickly, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Throttle down and use the front brake.
questions.answerB: Use the rear brake only.
questions.answerC: Use the front brake only.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: To stop quickly, apply both brakes at the same time.

questions.question: When you ride a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go by turning only your head. Keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance while turning. Your arms should be slightly bent any time you are holding the handgrips.

questions.question: If you cannot avoid a slippery road, you should:
questions.answerA: Lean into the slippery section to maintain your balance.
questions.answerB: Maintain your speed to improve traction.
questions.answerC: Not worry about the road conditions.
questions.answerD: Keep your motorcycle upright and proceed as slowly as needed.
questions.explanation: It is best to entirely avoid slippery stretches of road. However, if there is no way to avoid such an area, keep your motorcycle upright and proceed as slowly as possible.

questions.question: Switching to a lower gear is also known as:
questions.answerB: Acceleration.
questions.answerC: Upshifting.
questions.answerD: Coasting.
questions.explanation: Shifting to a lower gear causes an effect similar to using the brakes. For this reason, downshifting is also known as engine braking.

questions.question: Motorcycle riders:
questions.answerA: Should wear hearing protection at all times to prevent hearing damage.
questions.answerB: Should only wear hearing protection during long rides.
questions.answerC: Should not wear hearing protection because it will muffle other noises, such as horns and sirens.
questions.answerD: Do not need to use hearing protection if they are using a helmet.
questions.explanation: Longterm exposure to wind and engine noise can cause permanent hearing damage, even if the rider is wearing a full-face helmet. Wearing ear plugs or other hearing protection can guard against damage while still allowing the wearer to hear important sounds like horns and sirens.

questions.question: When an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator:
questions.answerB: Is about to stop.
questions.answerC: Plans to turn right.
questions.answerD: Is about to slow down.
questions.explanation: Instead of mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator plans to turn right or change lanes to the right.

questions.question: When checking tire pressure:
questions.answerA: Eyeballing the tire is a good method.
questions.answerB: Use a tire gauge.
questions.answerC: It is best to squeeze the tire.
questions.answerD: Compare the height of the tire to another tire.
questions.explanation: You should use a tire gauge to check the tire pressure before every ride. An under-inflated tire may still look okay, so a visual check is not enough.

questions.question: Smoothly downshifting on motorcycles:
questions.answerB: Can allow the rider to engine brake.
questions.answerC: Is illegal.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if other vehicles are around.
questions.explanation: Engine braking by smoothly downshifting can be a useful option for motorcyclists. If you choose to engine brake, apply your brake lights separately to let other drivers know that you are slowing down.

questions.question: Which of the following will help you ride safely on slippery surfaces?
questions.answerB: Using both brakes
questions.answerC: Using the center lane
questions.answerD: Maintaining or increasing your speed
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, reduce your speed, brake using both brakes, and avoid sudden moves. Avoid the center of the lane and instead follow tire tracks left by cars. Always keep an eye out for hazards that may make a road surface especially slippery, such as oil spots and loose gravel.

questions.question: Slippery surfaces can make it difficult to control a motorcycle. Which of the following would be considered a slippery surface?
questions.answerB: A driveway
questions.answerC: Dry pavement
questions.answerD: A parking lot
questions.explanation: Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be slippery surfaces. Motorcyclists should ride with extra caution when riding over slippery surfaces.

questions.question: To lean the motorcycle for a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Press the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Apply the front brake.
questions.answerD: Apply the rear brake.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle needs to lean in order to turn. To make this happen, press on the handgrip in the direction you want to turn.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle and trying to turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the grip in the direction you want to turn.
questions.answerB: Press the grip opposite of the direction you want to turn.
questions.answerC: Not hold the grip because it can be dangerous.
questions.answerD: Not lean the motorcycle as that can be unsafe.
questions.explanation: When traveling faster than a walking pace, your motorcycle will need to lean to turn. Pressing the grip in the direction you want to turn will cause you to lean in the appropriate direction

questions.question: A three-wheeled motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Handles curves about the same as a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Handles curves differently than a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Should not be operated in curves.
questions.answerD: Should use the shoulder when taking a curve.
questions.explanation: The cornering characteristics of a three-wheeled motorcycle or a motorcycle with a sidecar differ from those of a two-wheeled motorcycle.

questions.question: When riding in a group while passing another vehicle, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Allow one rider to fully pass the other vehicle before another rider begins to pass.
questions.answerB: Allow several members of the group to pass the other vehicle at once.
questions.answerC: Have the last rider in the group wave to the driver being passed to signal that no other motorcycles are approaching.
questions.answerD: Pass in a staggered formation.
questions.explanation: Riders in a group should overtake another vehicle one at a time. Each rider should complete their pass and resume their position in the group formation before the next rider begins to pass.

questions.question: Usually, a minimum following distance of _____ should be maintained.
questions.answerB: Two seconds
questions.answerC: Three seconds
questions.answerD: Four seconds
questions.explanation: Generally, you should maintain a minimum following distance of two seconds. Increase your following distance to at least three seconds whenever you are riding under conditions that are less than ideal.

questions.question: You should do a pre-ride inspection:
questions.answerB: About once every 10 rides.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a season.
questions.explanation: A small technical fault can have much more serious consequences on a motorcycle than on a car. To avoid these consequences, inspect your motorcycle before every ride.

questions.question: When going through a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stay in the same portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerB: Always stay in the left portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerC: Always stay in the right portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerD: Remember that the best path may not follow the curve of the road.
questions.explanation: Road and traffic conditions can change at any time. Always be prepared to change your lane position as appropriate no matter where you are on a roadway. The best path through a curve does not necessarily follow the curve of the road.

questions.question: Small vehicles can appear ______ and seem to be traveling ______ than they actually are.
questions.answerB: Farther away, faster
questions.answerC: Closer, more slowly
questions.answerD: Closer, faster
questions.explanation: Small vehicles, like motorcycles, can visually seem to be farther away and moving more slowly than they actually are. This phenomenon can make it difficult for others on the road to accurately judge the location and speed of a smaller vehicle.

questions.question: A linked braking system:
questions.answerA: Connects the front and rear brakes, applying both brakes when either brake lever is applied.
questions.answerB: Connects the front brake to the gear shifter, applying the brake when the rider downshifts.
questions.answerC: Connects the rear brake to a foot control.
questions.answerD: Connects the rear brake to a switch on the handlebar.
questions.explanation: A linked braking system connects the front and rear brakes on a motorcycle. This system applies braking pressure to both brakes when either the front or rear lever is used. Check your owner's manual for a detailed explanation of the braking system on your motorcycle.

questions.question: Keep an expanded cushion of space between your motorcycle and the vehicle in front of you:
questions.answerA: When conditions will make stopping more difficult than usual.
questions.answerB: When you want to look at the scenery.
questions.answerC: To encourage other drivers to cut you off.
questions.answerD: To prevent the driver in front of you from knowing you are there.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a larger following distance.

questions.question: Braking in a turn is:
questions.answerA: Easier than braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerB: More difficult than braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: Done safely by using the front brake only.
questions.answerD: Done safely by using the rear brake only.
questions.explanation: Braking in a turn is not as easy as braking on a straightaway. It is possible to use both brakes to brake in a turn, but the operator must know the proper technique and exercise great care.

questions.question: You have been drinking alcohol. If you wait an hour for each drink before riding your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and riding.
questions.answerB: Your riding skills will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Side effects from the drinking may still remain.
questions.answerD: You will be okay as long as you ride slowly.
questions.explanation: On average, the body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. However, some alcohol may accumulate in the body even if a person consumes only one drink per hour. Their abilities and judgment can still be impaired.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Ride more slowly than you would normally.
questions.answerB: Start slowing earlier than you would normally.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerD: Not communicate with the passenger while riding.
questions.explanation: Because of a passenger's additional weight, a motorcycle will respond more slowly with a passenger on board than with just one occupant. With a passenger, you should travel a bit more slowly than you normally would, start slowing sooner than you normally would, and increase your following distance. Always warn your passenger of any special conditions ahead.

questions.question: When braking, you should use:
questions.answerB: Only the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Both brakes.
questions.answerD: Either brake, but never both at the same time.
questions.explanation: Always simultaneously use both brakes to stop. The brakes are most effective when used at the same time.

questions.question: How much of a motorcycle's total braking power can the front brake supply?
questions.answerB: About 25 percent
questions.answerC: About 50 percent
questions.answerD: About 70 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. It supplies at least three-quarters of the motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: As a motorcycle operator, you can help others see you by:
questions.answerB: Wearing bright clothing.
questions.answerC: Following other vehicles closely.
questions.answerD: Not using turn signals.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen, wear brightly-colored clothing, use your headlight at all times, and use your turn signals.

questions.question: Crashes are more likely to occur among:
questions.answerB: Beginning riders.
questions.answerC: Those familiar with their motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Those who have completed a safety course.
questions.explanation: Crashes are the most likely to occur for untrained, beginning riders who are unfamiliar with their motorcycle.

questions.question: Moving into another lane while taking a curve is often the result of:
questions.answerB: Lanes that are too narrow.
questions.answerC: Not knowing how to steer.
questions.answerD: Lanes that are too wide.
questions.explanation: Trying to enter a curve or turn at a speed that is too fast for conditions may cause you to cross into another lane of traffic or leave the road entirely.

questions.question: A properly-fitted motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Allows the rider to touch the ground with their feet while seated.
questions.answerB: Has a seat even with the rider's waist.
questions.answerC: Has a seat that is 10 inches above the rider's waist.
questions.answerD: Has a seat that is 10 inches below the rider's waist.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle fits you properly, your feet should be able to reach the ground while you are seated. When riding your motorcycle, keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: After drinking, what lessens the effects of alcohol?
questions.answerB: Coffee
questions.answerC: Time
questions.answerD: Food
questions.explanation: The liver burns alcohol at a set rate, and there is nothing you can do to speed along the process. The only way to lessen the effects of alcohol is to give your body the time needed to remove it.

questions.question: When choosing a helmet, you will get the most protection by using a helmet that:
questions.answerB: Meets U.S. DOT standards.
questions.answerC: Has survived a previous crash.
questions.answerD: Provides hearing protection.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you are getting as much protection as possible, choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. Helmets should fit snugly all the way around.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good way for a rider to increase their visibility?
questions.answerB: Using their headlight at all times
questions.answerC: Using their turn signals
questions.answerD: Waving at other drivers
questions.explanation: To make yourself visible to other road users, you should wear brightly-colored clothing with reflective materials, use your headlight at all times, and use your signals and brake light properly.

questions.question: A driver making eye contact with you:
questions.answerB: Will never happen.
questions.answerC: Does not mean that they will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: Guarantees that they will properly yield to you.
questions.explanation: You should never count on eye contact to guarantee that a driver will yield to you. It is not uncommon for drivers to look directly at a motorcyclist but fail to consciously notice them.

questions.question: When being passed, you should not move to the portion of the lane farthest from the passing driver because it:
questions.answerA: Discourages the passing driver from cutting into your lane too early.
questions.answerB: Encourages the passing driver to cut into your lane too early.
questions.answerC: Encourages the passing driver to complete the pass as quickly as possible.
questions.answerD: Encourages other drivers to pass you.
questions.explanation: Moving into the portion of your lane farthest from a passing vehicle is potentially dangerous because it could encourage the driver to return to your lane before it is safe to do so. It is safest to stay in the center of a lane when being passed.

questions.question: Riding gloves are often:
questions.answerB: Made of wool.
questions.answerC: Not pre-curved.
questions.answerD: Unsafe for the rider.
questions.explanation: Gloves designed for motorcycle riding are usually made of leather. In addition to improving your grip, gloves provide protection for a rider's hands and fingers.

questions.question: A street-legal motorcycle must have all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Good tires.
questions.answerC: Front and rear brakes.
questions.answerD: A flag.
questions.explanation: In Kentucky, a motorcycle is required to have a rearview mirror; one headlight with high and low beam settings; a taillight; a horn; a muffler and tailpipe; a brake light; front and rear brakes; and good tires. A motorcycle must also be properly registered and covered by liability insurance.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signals to indicate that you plan to change lanes.
questions.answerB: Tailgate other drivers.
questions.answerC: Keep your eyes focused no more than 15 feet in front of your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Not use a headlight during the day.
questions.explanation: To lessen the chances of a crash occurring, you should make yourself visible, communicate your intentions to others, maintain adequate space cushions, search your path of travel at least 12 seconds ahead, identify and separate hazards, and be prepared to react to changing conditions.

questions.question: Who should set the pace in a group of riders?
questions.answerB: The riders just behind the leader
questions.answerC: The rider in back
questions.answerD: The oldest rider
questions.explanation: The last rider in a group of motorcyclists should set the pace of travel. Having the last rider set the pace will ensure that no riders are left behind.

questions.question: When should your rearview mirror be adjusted?
questions.answerB: Before starting the motorcycle
questions.answerC: During the ride
questions.answerD: At a traffic signal
questions.explanation: You should clean and adjust both mirrors before starting your motorcycle. Adjust your mirrors so you can see the lane behind you and as much as possible of the lane next to you.

questions.question: On a slippery surface, you should not:
questions.answerB: Avoid making sudden moves.
questions.answerC: Use only the front brake when slowing or stopping.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes when slowing or stopping.
questions.explanation: To ride safely on a slippery surface, you should use both brakes when slowing or stopping, reduce your speed, and avoid making sudden moves. Be alert to oily areas, dirt, gravel, shaded areas, and bridges, as these surfaces are more likely to be slippery than others.

questions.question: What is often found in the center portion of the lane?
questions.answerB: An oily or greasy strip
questions.answerC: Lane markings
questions.answerD: Ice
questions.explanation: Drippings from cars tend to form an oily strip in the center of each lane. Unless conditions are wet, it is usually still safe for a motorcycle to operate on the center strip.

questions.question: If your motorcycle starts to wobble, it is best to:
questions.answerB: Accelerate.
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and close the throttle gradually.
questions.answerD: Gradually apply your brakes.
questions.explanation: Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble because doing so will only make the motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down by gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as possible, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Avoid applying the brakes, as this may also worsen the wobble.

questions.question: A motorcycle “fits” you if:
questions.answerA: You are able to touch your feet to the ground while seated.
questions.answerB: You are able to reach the controls by stretching.
questions.answerC: The handlebars go over your head.
questions.answerD: Your feet are unable to rest on the foot pegs.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle fits you properly if your feet can reach the ground while you are seated on the motorcycle. It should be easy for you to reach and operate the controls.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride slower than the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and the brakes.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Pull in the clutch when turning.
questions.explanation: To help reduce your reaction time, you should cover the clutch and brakes. This is especially helpful when riding through areas where potential hazards are likely.

questions.question: If your front wheel skids as a result of braking, you should:
questions.answerB: Release the front brake immediately and re-apply the brake smoothly.
questions.answerC: Release the front brake and only use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Release both brakes and coast to a stop.
questions.explanation: If your front wheel locks as a result of braking, you should release the front brake immediately and re-apply the brake smoothly.

questions.question: Which vest or jacket color would best help you to be seen?
questions.answerB: Black
questions.answerC: Silver
questions.answerD: Blue
questions.explanation: Wearing brightly-colored clothing while riding will increase your chances of being seen. Bright oranges, yellows, reds, or greens are best and are preferable to drab or dark colors.

questions.question: Which types of brakes do most motorcycles have?
questions.answerB: Rear and emergency
questions.answerC: Front and rear
questions.answerD: Only a front brake
questions.explanation: Motorcycles generally have one brake for each wheel. The front brake carries more braking power than the rear brake.

questions.question: In a normal turn:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle and rider should lean together.
questions.answerB: The motorcycle and rider should lean in opposite directions.
questions.answerC: The motorcycle should lean, but the rider should not.
questions.answerD: The rider should lean, but the motorcycle should not.
questions.explanation: During normal turns, the motorcycle and the rider should be leaning together at the same angle. In slow, tight turns, only the motorcycle should lean while the rider keeps their body straight up.

questions.question: You should check your tires for all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Tread.
questions.answerC: General wear.
questions.answerD: Flexibility.
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-ride inspection of your motorcycle, you should check the air pressure, general wear, and tread of your tires.

questions.question: What does this signal mean?
questions.answerB: High beams on
questions.answerC: Turn right
questions.answerD: Hazard
questions.explanation: Signals are an important part of communication when riding in groups. When the lead rider's right leg is extended, it means there is a hazard in the roadway on their right side.

questions.question: Most crashes happen:
questions.answerB: After several hours of riding.
questions.answerC: On short trips.
questions.answerD: On long trips.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen on trips that are shorter than five miles in length at speeds slower than 30 mph.

questions.question: If your friend has been drinking alcohol, it is a good idea to do any of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Arrange for a safe ride home for your friend.
questions.answerB: Occupy your friend with activities to distract them from drinking.
questions.answerC: Keep your friend from leaving until they are sober.
questions.answerD: Allow your friend to ride their motorcycle.
questions.explanation: There are several strategies you can use to prevent someone from riding their motorcycle while impaired. You can arrange another way for them to get home, involve them in other activities to slow the pace of their drinking, use any available excuse to stop them from leaving before they are sober, and get other friends involved to intervene as a group.

questions.question: When being passed by another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the left portion of your lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the center portion of your lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Try to get onto the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally safest to ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding on the side of the lane nearest the passing driver increases the danger of a collision, and riding on the side farthest from the passing driver may tempt them to return to your lane too soon.

questions.question: A motorcycle with a sidecar:
questions.answerB: Can tip over if making a turn too fast.
questions.answerC: Is designed to take corners at any speed.
questions.answerD: Should not be used for loading items.
questions.explanation: Even with three wheels on the ground, a sidecar can tip over if it is being turned too sharply or is moving too fast for a corner.

questions.question: Before changing lanes, motorcycle riders should turn their heads to look over their shoulders because:
questions.answerA: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like other vehicles.
questions.answerB: They can catch the attention of other drivers by turning their heads.
questions.answerC: Mirrors are not really helpful.
questions.answerD: They should try to make eye contact with surrounding drivers.
questions.explanation: Like any other vehicle, a motorcycle has blind spots that cannot be seen by a rider using their mirrors. A motorcyclist should always turn their head to check for vehicles or other hazards in their blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: A motorcyclist's cushion of space:
questions.answerB: Should vary according to riding conditions.
questions.answerC: Is not necessary in most situations.
questions.answerD: Should be avoided to keep traffic moving safely.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up your following distance.

questions.question: When loading cargo onto a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Pack heavier items in front of the tank bag.
questions.answerB: Pack lighter items near the front.
questions.answerC: Try to not place items over the rear axle.
questions.answerD: Place items behind the rear axle.
questions.explanation: Heavier items should be loaded in front of the tank bag. You should try to place the load over or in front of the rear axle. Putting the load behind the rear axle may affect your control.

questions.question: As an operator, you should prepare a passenger to ride by instructing them to do each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle after the engine has been started.
questions.answerB: Sit as far forward as possible.
questions.answerC: Maintain a large space between themselves and you.
questions.answerD: Keep their legs away from the muffler and chains.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a ride, you should ask your passenger to mount the motorcycle only after the engine has been started. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding you and hold onto the motorcycle's passenger handholds or onto your waist, hips, or belt. They should keep their legs away from the muffler, chains, and other moving parts.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, you should look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: When adjusting your mirrors, you should focus on:
questions.answerA: The road behind and to the side of your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Your arms.
questions.answerC: The road in front of your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: The side of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Adjust your mirrors so you can see the lane behind you and as much as possible of the lane next to you. When properly adjusted, a mirror may show the edge of your arm or shoulder, but it’s the road behind you and to the side of you that is most important.

questions.question: The front brake supplies how much of a motorcycle's potential stopping power?
questions.answerB: About 50 percent
questions.answerC: About 70 percent
questions.answerD: 100 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake and can provide at least 70 percent of the motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: In New Hampshire, a person who is age 21 or older with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of ______ is considered legally intoxicated.
questions.answerB: 0.04 percent
questions.answerC: 0.06 percent
questions.answerD: 0.08 percent
questions.explanation: A person who is of legal drinking age with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher is considered legally intoxicated. It is both illegal and unsafe to ride a motorcycle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: If road conditions require a longer stopping distance than normal, you should:
questions.answerB: Increase your usual following distance.
questions.answerC: Travel on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Ask someone else to operate your motorcycle.
questions.explanation: An increased following distance is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a minimum three-second following distance.

questions.question: A way to lower the risk of being involved in a crash is to:
questions.answerA: Communicate your intentions to other road users.
questions.answerB: Not look ahead while riding.
questions.answerC: Wear dark clothes.
questions.answerD: Ride in the parts of a lane that make it difficult to be seen.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: How do headache, cold, and hay fever medications usually affect your body?
questions.answerB: They make you more alert.
questions.answerC: They make you hungry.
questions.answerD: They make you unable to concentrate.
questions.explanation: Most drugs taken to ease headaches, colds, hay fever, allergies, or nerves can make the consumer drowsy and may impair their ability to ride safely. When taking a medication, it is important for a rider to know how the drug affects their body before riding.

questions.question: Successful motorcyclists know they are safest when they are:
questions.answerB: Faster than other vehicles.
questions.answerC: On the side of the road.
questions.answerD: In the left side of the lane.
questions.explanation: Successful motorcyclists know that they are safest when they are clearly seen by other road users. Use your headlight, brake light, signals, and lane position to maximize your visibility.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: The pass may be completed in a no passing zone.
questions.answerB: The rider may travel up to 10 mph over the speed limit to complete the pass.
questions.answerC: The pass must be started and completed within a passing zone.
questions.answerD: The pass must be completed on the shoulder, if one is present.
questions.explanation: Passing must be completed within the posted speed limits, and only in areas where passing is safe and legal.

questions.question: Most crashes occur during the day. To lessen the chance of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerB: Wear brightly-colored clothing.
questions.answerC: Not ride during the day.
questions.answerD: Look for safer routes.
questions.explanation: To minimize your chances of being in a crash, you should make yourself as visible as possible by wearing brightly-colored clothing when riding, even during the day.

questions.question: An advantage to keeping the size of a group of riders small is:
questions.answerA: A small group is less easily separated in traffic than a larger group.
questions.answerB: A small group can disregard traffic laws to stay together.
questions.answerC: Riders will always be trying to catch up to the group.
questions.answerD: It will be difficult to keep track of where everyone is.
questions.explanation: There are several advantages to keeping groups of riders small. In comparison to a large group, a small group is easier for other vehicles to pass safely, is less likely to get separated by traffic or stop lights, and creates less need for slower riders to hurry to catch up to the rest of the group.

questions.question: Before riding, check all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: The amount of tread on your tires.
questions.answerC: The reflective quality of your tires.
questions.answerD: The general condition of the sidewalls on your tires.
questions.explanation: Before every ride, be sure to check your tires' inflation pressure, your tires' treadwear, and the general condition of the sidewalls and tread surface on the tires.

questions.question: The single most important thing you can do to improve your chances of surviving a crash is to:
questions.answerA: Wear a high-quality helmet that is securely fastened.
questions.answerB: Wear shorts.
questions.answerC: Wear sneakers.
questions.answerD: Wear goggles.
questions.explanation: The single most effective action you can take to improve your chances of surviving a crash is to wear a high-quality helmet that is securely fastened.

questions.question: If you are preparing to pass another operator on the left, you should:
questions.answerA: Get into the right part of the lane so you can be seen in their side mirror.
questions.answerB: Get into the left part of the lane to increase your line of sight.
questions.answerC: Stay in the center part of the lane so you can be seen in their rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: Weave in your lane to draw attention to yourself.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, ride in the left portion of your lane to increase your line of sight and to make yourself more visible to any drivers in the passing lane. Use your mirrors and turn your head to check for traffic before changing lanes.

questions.question: Which of the following provides a rider with the best protection?
questions.answerB: A face shield
questions.answerC: A windshield
questions.answerD: Eyeglasses
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield provides protection for your entire face in the event of a crash. Goggles will protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield or eyeglasses are not a substitute for either goggles or a face shield.

questions.question: To help other drivers see you, you should wear:
questions.answerB: Brightly-colored clothes.
questions.answerC: Lights.
questions.answerD: A black jacket.
questions.explanation: Wearing brightly-colored clothing will help you to be seen by other road users. Wear clothes that increase your visibility both during the day and at night.

questions.question: When choosing clothes for riding, which of the following is not a good choice?
questions.answerA: A jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs completely
questions.answerB: Boots or shoes that cover your ankles
questions.answerC: Gloves made of leather
questions.answerD: A baseball cap to cover your hair
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: As you slow or stop, you should:
questions.answerB: Shift down through the gears.
questions.answerC: Take the bike out of gear.
questions.answerD: Stay in the same gear.
questions.explanation: You should shift down through the gears with the clutch as you slow or stop. Stay in first gear while you are stopped so you can move quickly, if needed.

questions.question: A motorcyclist:
questions.answerA: Is always required to wear a helmet.
questions.answerB: Must wear a helmet if they are carrying a passenger on their motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Does not have to wear a helmet if they are over the age of 21 and have held their motorcycle license for a year or longer.
questions.answerD: Does not have to wear a helmet if they are over the age of 18.
questions.explanation: A person may operate a motorcycle without a helmet if they are over the age of 21 and have held a motorcycle license for at least one year. It is recommended that all motorcyclists wear helmets every time they ride.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection usually takes:
questions.answerA: A few minutes and should be done no more than once a month.
questions.answerB: A few minutes and should be done before every ride.
questions.answerC: Over an hour and should be performed by a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Over an hour and must only be done if you will be carrying a passenger.
questions.explanation: Conduct a thorough pre-ride inspection before every ride. It should usually take only a few minutes.

questions.question: Your primary source for information about your motorcycle should be:
questions.answerB: A book about motorcycles.
questions.answerC: A former owner.
questions.answerD: Someone knowledgeable about motorcycles.
questions.explanation: Your owner's manual should be your primary source for information about your specific motorcycle. Your manual will include information about the motorcycle's specifications, operation, and suggested maintenance.

questions.question: Swerving a motorcycle:
questions.answerB: Requires little traction.
questions.answerC: Is a slow maneuver.
questions.answerD: Should be done to avoid a hazard on a slippery road.
questions.explanation: Swerving is a quick maneuver that requires a lot of traction in order to be safely executed. Making sudden moves, such as swerving, on slippery surfaces should be avoided.

questions.question: Which formation is best for keeping the riders in a group close together?
questions.answerB: Staggered
questions.answerC: Single-file
questions.answerD: Compressed
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is generally the best way for a group to maintain close ranks while also allowing each rider to maintain an adequate cushion of space. A single-file formation is preferable when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: Just like cars, motorcycles have blind spots. When switching lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and check your blind spot.
questions.answerB: Look only at your mirrors.
questions.answerC: Rely on your peripheral vision.
questions.answerD: Slow down so any vehicle in your blind spot can pass you.
questions.explanation: Blind spots, by definition, are areas that you cannot see by just looking in your mirrors. Turn your head to the side and check over your shoulder for vehicles in your blind spot before you change lanes.

questions.question: An advantage to keeping a cushion of space between your motorcycle and other vehicles is that:
questions.answerA: You can pass danger more quickly.
questions.answerB: You will have a more narrow view of the road so you can stay focused.
questions.answerC: You will have more time to react to the movements of others.
questions.answerD: You can more easily follow the path of the next vehicle.
questions.explanation: Maintaining a cushion of space between your motorcycle and other vehicles on the road will give you a clearer view of any emerging hazards, more time to react to hazards, and more space to maneuver around them.

questions.question: The front brake supplies approximately how much of a motorcycle's potential stopping power?
questions.answerB: About 50 percent
questions.answerC: About 70 percent
questions.answerD: About 95 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. The front brake supplies at least 70 percent of a motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: When riding in a group, the best way to keep ranks close while maintaining an adequate safety cushion is to ride:
questions.answerB: In a staggered formation.
questions.answerC: In a single-file line.
questions.answerD: In a passing formation.
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is the best way to keep ranks close while still maintaining an adequate space cushion for all riders. Ride in a single-file line when riding in curves, turning, or entering or leaving a highway. Never ride side-by-side with another rider.

questions.question: The control for the rear brake is usually located:
questions.answerB: On the left handlebar.
questions.answerC: Near the left foot.
questions.answerD: Near the right foot.
questions.explanation: The rear brake of a motorcycle is usually operated with the right foot.

questions.question: If your motorcycle starts to wobble, you should:
questions.answerB: Use the brakes immediately.
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and gradually close the throttle.
questions.answerD: Downshift.
questions.explanation: Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble because doing so will only make the motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down by gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as possible, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Avoid applying the brakes, as this may also worsen the wobble.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to wobble, you should:
questions.answerB: Use the brakes gradually.
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and close the throttle gradually.
questions.answerD: Downshift.
questions.explanation: Trying to accelerate out of a wobble is dangerous and will only make your motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly (without trying to fight the wobble), gradually close the throttle to slow down, and move your weight as far forward and downward as possible. Pull off the road as soon as you can.

questions.question: ____ can remove alcohol and its effects from your body.
questions.answerB: Coffee
questions.answerC: Exercise
questions.answerD: Fresh air
questions.explanation: The only method that effectively reduces your BAC is not drinking alcohol for a period of time. Coffee, exercise, fresh air, and cold showers cannot reduce your BAC or change the effects of alcohol. They can help you remain awake, but they cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: When riding in a group, motorcyclists:
questions.answerB: Should increase their space cushions.
questions.answerC: Should reduce their usual space cushions by half.
questions.answerD: Should maintain adequate space cushions.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, you should maintain close ranks but still keep an adequate space cushion around each rider.

questions.question: At a minimum, how often should a motorcycle's hydraulic fluid be checked?
questions.answerB: Once a week
questions.answerC: Once a year
questions.answerD: Before every ride
questions.explanation: Pre-ride motorcycle inspections are an important part of ensuring safe riding. Hydraulic fluids and coolants should be checked at least once a week.

questions.question: The faster you drink:
questions.answerA: The more the alcohol will accumulate in your body.
questions.answerB: The faster the alcohol is removed from your body.
questions.answerC: The more minimal the effects of the alcohol will be.
questions.answerD: The more likely you will be able to evade being pulled over.
questions.explanation: The faster you drink, the more alcohol will accumulate in your body. It is never safe to operate a motor vehicle after drinking alcohol in any amount.

questions.question: If the chain or belt of your motorcycle breaks, you will:
questions.answerA: Experience a sudden increase in power to the rear wheel.
questions.answerB: Experience a sudden loss of power to the rear wheel.
questions.answerC: Experience a sudden loss of power to the front wheel.
questions.answerD: Experience a sudden increase in power to the front wheel.
questions.explanation: If your drive chain or belt fails, you will experience an immediate loss of power to the rear wheel.

questions.question: A major effect of alcohol consumption is:
questions.answerB: The slowing down of bodily functions.
questions.answerC: Increasing nervousness.
questions.answerD: Increasing alertness.
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a depressant. It slows down and impairs bodily functions, both physical and mental.

questions.question: A proper lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerB: Help you avoid surface hazards.
questions.answerC: Help you avoid traffic signals.
questions.answerD: Communicate your intentions to other road users.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: Where is the throttle usually located?
questions.answerB: Near the right footrest
questions.answerC: On the left handle grip
questions.answerD: On the right handle grip
questions.explanation: The throttle of a motorcycle is usually located on the right handle grip. Be sure to know where all of your motorcycle's controls are located before riding.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use your turn signals when changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Follow other vehicles closely.
questions.answerC: Watch about five feet ahead of your motorcycle while riding.
questions.answerD: Always be ready to use crash-avoidance techniques.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle. Always be ready to avoid an unexpected hazard.

questions.question: When may you not need to increase your following distance?
questions.answerB: When there is a lot of traffic
questions.answerC: When you can see through the vehicle in front of you
questions.answerD: When it is raining
questions.explanation: An increased following distance is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a longer following distance.

questions.question: Making eye contact with another driver:
questions.answerA: Indicates that the driver sees you.
questions.answerB: Doesn’t mean that the driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerC: Guarantees that the other driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: May make the driver mad.
questions.explanation: Never rely on eye contact as an assurance that a driver will properly yield to you. It is common for drivers to look directly at motorcyclists and still fail to notice them.

questions.question: The front brake:
questions.answerA: Provides less than half of a motorcycle's braking power.
questions.answerB: Provides about 70 percent of a motorcycle's braking power.
questions.answerC: Should not be used unless the roadway is wet.
questions.answerD: Should be the only brake you use.
questions.explanation: The front brake is much more powerful than the rear one and provides at least 70 percent of a motorcycle's total stopping power. Use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: Which of the following types of clothing can help you to be seen by other drivers?
questions.answerB: Clothes made from synthetic materials
questions.answerC: Reflective clothes
questions.answerD: A leather jacket
questions.explanation: Be sure to wear gear that can help you and your motorcycle to be spotted by other road users. Bright, reflective clothing can make it easier for others to see you.

questions.question: To effectively provide protection for a motorcycle rider, pants should:
questions.answerA: Be made of a soft material.
questions.answerB: Be made of a heavy material.
questions.answerC: Fit loosely enough that they flap in the wind.
questions.answerD: Be short and expose some parts of the legs.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should wear pants that cover your entire legs and are made of leather or another sturdy synthetic material. Clothing should fit snugly enough that it does not flap in the wind but not so snugly that it restricts your movement.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerB: In front of the group.
questions.answerC: At the tail end of the group.
questions.answerD: Beside the leader.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, riders with less experience should be positioned toward the front of the group, just behind the leader. This will allow more experienced riders to keep an eye on them without forcing the inexperienced rider to lead the group.

questions.question: The best way to stop quickly is to:
questions.answerB: Use the front brake first.
questions.answerC: Throttle down and use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: If you need to stop quickly, apply both the front and rear brakes at the same time.

questions.question: Drivers on an entrance ramp may not see you on the highway. What should you do to help an entering driver merge safely?
questions.answerA: Stay in your lane, as it is not your responsibility to be seen.
questions.answerB: Change to a lane away from the entrance ramp, if possible.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Weave within your lane to be more obvious to the entering driver.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision, always allow merging vehicles plenty of space to safely enter traffic. Change lanes away from the entrance ramp if there is room to do so safely. If there isn't another lane available, adjust your speed to open up space for the merging driver.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should be placed:
questions.answerA: In the front of the group.
questions.answerB: Just behind the lead rider.
questions.answerC: At the back of the group.
questions.answerD: Anywhere within the group.
questions.explanation: Inexperienced riders should ride near the front of a group, just behind the leader, so more experienced riders can keep an eye on them from behind.

questions.question: A passenger should never:
questions.answerB: Lean when the operator leans.
questions.answerC: Wear clothing that is tight.
questions.answerD: Ride sidesaddle.
questions.explanation: In South Carolina, passengers under the age of 21 must wear a helmet and eye protection, though it is recommended that all motorcycle riders wear helmets and eye protection. Passengers should avoid wearing loose clothing that might catch on the motorcycle and should always lean with the operator when turning. Passengers should never be allowed to ride sidesaddle.

questions.question: Goggles will:
questions.answerB: Be an equally as effective as a face shield.
questions.answerC: Offer the same protection as a windshield.
questions.answerD: Provide protection for your entire face.
questions.explanation: Wearing goggles provides protection for your eyes, but not for the rest of your face. A face shield provides protection for your whole face and is recommended above goggles. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for a face shield or goggles.

questions.question: To provide the best protection to the wearer, boots or shoes should:
questions.answerA: Be made of a soft material.
questions.answerB: Have long laces that are not tucked in.
questions.answerC: Cover the ankle and provide support.
questions.answerD: Have tall heels.
questions.explanation: For riding, choose boots or heavy shoes that are tall and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Heels should be low so that they won't catch on rough surfaces. Tuck in long laces so that they don't catch on the motorcycle's moving parts.

questions.question: When operating a motorcycle on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerD: Use only the rear brake.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should reduce your speed. Make certain to use both brakes when braking and avoid making sudden moves.

questions.question: Before mounting a motorcycle, you should check all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: The air pressure in the tires.
questions.answerB: Fluid levels.
questions.answerC: The turn signals.
questions.answerD: Damage to the paint.
questions.explanation: Before getting on a motorcycle, you should check the tread and air pressure of the tires, the oil and fluid levels, the lights, and the signals.

questions.question: If you lock the rear tire on a good traction surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Release and re-apply the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Keep it locked until you completely stop.
questions.answerC: Release the rear brake and only use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Release the rear brake and use both brakes to stop.
questions.explanation: If you accidentally lock the rear brake on a good traction surface, you can keep it locked until you have completely stopped. You should still be able to steer your motorcycle with a locked rear wheel.

questions.question: The center portion of a lane often contains an oily strip. This strip:
questions.answerA: Is not safe for motorcyclists at any time.
questions.answerB: Is usually safe for motorcyclists, unless it is raining.
questions.answerC: Should always be avoided since other parts of the lane do not have the oily strip.
questions.answerD: Adds to traction for most motorcycle tires.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars collect in a strip in the center of a traffic lane. Unless the road is wet, this area will generally still provide enough traction for motorcyclists to ride safely. Because the strip is usually no more than two feet wide, it is often possible to ride to one side of the strip and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: It is a good idea to wear reflective clothing:
questions.answerB: During the day.
questions.answerC: At dusk.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Wearing reflective and brightly-colored clothing is always a good idea when riding a motorcycle. Crashes occur in broad daylight and at night, so it is best to wear highly visible clothing at any time of day.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger, a motorcyclist should tell the passenger to:
questions.answerA: Sit as far back as possible.
questions.answerB: Hold onto the seat.
questions.answerC: Put their feet on the muffler.
questions.answerD: Mount the motorcycle after the motorcycle has been started.
questions.explanation: Even if your passenger is also a motorcyclist, you should give them complete safety instructions before leaving on a trip. Ask them to get on the motorcycle only after you have started the engine. They should sit as far forward as possible without crowding you and firmly hold onto your waist, hips, or belt. They should keep both feet on the footrests at all times, even when the bike is stopped.

questions.question: During the day, your headlight should:
questions.answerB: Be used on its high beam setting.
questions.answerC: Be used on its low beam setting.
questions.answerD: Alternate between high beam and low beam settings.
questions.explanation: Using your high beam headlight during the day increases the likelihood that other drivers will see you. Use your high beam headlight any time you are not riding behind or approaching other vehicles.

questions.question: Reflective clothing should:
questions.answerB: Be worn only during the day.
questions.answerC: Be worn only at night.
questions.answerD: Be worn day and night.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes occur in broad daylight. Increasing your visibility by wearing bright colors and reflective materials is a good idea at all times.

questions.question: Which of the following will best protect your eyes from wind?
questions.answerB: Sunglasses
questions.answerC: A windshield
questions.answerD: Goggles
questions.explanation: Goggles and face shields will help protect your eyes from wind. Most windshields, as well as eyeglasses or sunglasses, will not.

questions.question: One of the benefits of performing regular maintenance on your motorcycle is that:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle will ride well for a long period of time.
questions.answerB: The maintenance check will take a lot of time.
questions.answerC: Maintenance will be costly.
questions.answerD: Maintenance checks can often prevent parking tickets.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle will continue to ride like new if it is properly maintained and routine inspections become a part of its regular maintenance cycle.

questions.question: When looking for a protective jacket or pair of pants, you should look for:
questions.answerB: Items made of polyester.
questions.answerC: Items made of light materials.
questions.answerD: Items that are darkly-colored.
questions.explanation: It is safest to wear long pants and a jacket to fully cover your arms and legs while riding. Clothing made of leather can provide the highest level of protection.

questions.question: You will ______ hear a tire going flat.
questions.answerB: Usually
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: Seldom
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists will seldom hear their tire go flat. Tire failure is more commonly indicated by a sudden change in handling.

questions.question: Which of the following should you inspect during a pre-ride check?
questions.answerA: The general wear and tread of your tires
questions.answerB: The amount of cushion your seat has
questions.answerC: The shine of your paint
questions.answerD: The wind direction
questions.explanation: Before setting off on any ride, you should do a thorough check of your motorcycle. Inspect the tires, oil and fluid levels, headlight, tail light, turn signals, brake light, clutch and throttle, mirrors, brakes, and horn.

questions.question: Motorcycle riders should not rely on their mirrors to see what’s going on around them because:
questions.answerA: Motorcycle mirrors are smaller than the mirrors on other vehicles, so you can't see as much.
questions.answerB: Motorcycles, like cars, have blind spots.
questions.answerC: Mirrors are never accurate.
questions.answerD: Mirrors take your eyes off the road in front of you and they should not be used.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles, like any other vehicle, have blind spots. Therefore, you cannot rely only on your mirrors to know what is happening behind you. Frequent head checks should be part of your normal routine.

questions.question: When stopping behind a vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop far behind the vehicle, then slowly creep up.
questions.answerB: Stay well behind the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Make a quick stop right behind the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Stay about four car lengths behind the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Stay well behind the vehicle in front of you, even if you are both stopped. The vehicle could back up unexpectedly, or you may need space to get out of the way of another vehicle bearing down on you from behind.

questions.question: If a rider in a group wants to ride faster than the others, what should the group do?
questions.answerA: Let the rider go ahead and meet up at a designated spot later.
questions.answerB: Speed up to accommodate the one rider.
questions.answerC: Split up and have every rider travel as fast or as slow as they want.
questions.answerD: Let the rider that wants to go faster lead the group.
questions.explanation: If one member of a group wants to ride faster than the others, it is best to let them go ahead of the group and meet at a designated spot later.

questions.question: Passing and being passed when riding a motorcycle is not much different than when driving a car. However:
questions.answerA: A motorcycle's visibility is more critical than that of a car.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle's visibility is not as important as that of a car.
questions.answerC: Passing should be done on the shoulder instead of on the main roadway.
questions.answerD: It is critical to make eye contact with the other driver when riding a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: While the basic techniques for safely passing and being passed are the same as when driving a car, visibility is more critical when riding a motorcycle. The smaller size of a motorcycle makes it easier for you to disappear into another vehicle's blind spot, or for the driver to fail to notice you even if they are able to see you.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should:
questions.answerA: Either brake then swerve or swerve then brake.
questions.answerB: Brake and swerve at the same time.
questions.answerC: Choose to either brake or swerve.
questions.answerD: Not swerve and only use the front brake to stop.
questions.explanation: If a hazard requires you to brake and swerve to avoid a collision, you should take the actions separately. Do not brake while swerving because doing so may cause your motorcycle to fall over.

questions.question: Generally, the body eliminates how many alcoholic drinks per hour?
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: Three
questions.answerD: Four
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. The amount of time required to lower a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) can vary, so it is safest not to operate any motor vehicle after consuming any amount of alcohol.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked cars to your right when there is no oncoming traffic to your left, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay toward the right side of your lane.
questions.answerB: Stay toward the left side of your lane.
questions.answerC: Look to your left frequently.
questions.answerD: Use your rearview mirrors more frequently than usual.
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked cars, it is generally best to stay on the side of your lane that is not directly next to the cars. This will help to protect you from potential hazards like car doors being opened or people stepping out from between the cars. If there is traffic coming from the opposite direction, it is a good idea to stay in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: Helmeted riders are ________ more likely to survive than those not wearing helmets at the time of a crash.
questions.answerB: Three times
questions.answerC: Eight times
questions.answerD: Ten times
questions.explanation: At any speed, wearing a helmet will make you three times more likely to survive head injuries in the event of a crash than you would if not wearing a helmet.

questions.question: Most motorcycles have rounded, or convex, mirrors. These mirrors:
questions.answerA: Are easy to get used to right away.
questions.answerB: Make cars seem closer than they actually are.
questions.answerC: Provide a narrow view of the road.
questions.answerD: Make cars seem farther away than they actually are.
questions.explanation: In comparison to flat mirrors, convex mirrors provide a wider view of the road behind you. They also make objects seem farther away than they actually are. You should practice judging distances in convex mirrors if you are not used to them.

questions.question: An approved helmet:
questions.answerA: Allows the wearer to see as far to the sides as is necessary for safe riding.
questions.answerB: Looks good.
questions.answerC: Does not have a chin strap.
questions.answerD: Protects the wearer's hearing.
questions.explanation: While some people believe that a helmet will limit their vision, this is not the case. Any U.S. Department of Transportation-approved helmet will allow the wearer to see as far as is needed for safe riding.

questions.question: If hazards are on your left, you should ride:
questions.answerA: In the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: In the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: In any portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When hazards exist to your left, it is often best to ride in the right portion of the lane. Be prepared to adjust your lane position as road and traffic conditions change.

questions.question: Which formation is best for a group of riders entering a curve?
questions.answerB: Staggered
questions.answerC: Single-file
questions.answerD: Compressed
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is generally the best way for a group to maintain close ranks while also allowing each rider to maintain an adequate cushion of space. A single-file formation is preferable when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: It is recommended that a motorcyclist:
questions.answerB: Shift gears before a turn.
questions.answerC: Change power suddenly in a turn.
questions.answerD: Ride the brake throughout the turn.
questions.explanation: It is recommended that you change gears prior to entering a turn.

questions.question: When you have mounted your motorcycle, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Make sure the mirrors are clean.
questions.answerB: Make sure the horn works.
questions.answerC: Close the fuel supply valve.
questions.answerD: Make sure the clutch works smoothly.
questions.explanation: After mounting your motorcycle, you should make sure the clutch, throttle, horn, and brakes all work properly. Clean and adjust the mirrors and make sure that the fuel supply valve is open.

questions.question: In which of the following situations should you increase your following distance?
questions.answerB: Traffic is heavy.
questions.answerC: You are able to see the roadway through vehicles in front of you.
questions.answerD: There is pleasant and clear weather.
questions.explanation: While a two-second following distance is generally adequate, you should increase your following distance any time conditions would require a longer stopping distance, such as when the pavement is slippery due to poor weather conditions. Additionally, you should increase your following distance at night, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead, and when traffic is heavy.

questions.question: An adequate cushion of space between your motorcycle and other vehicles:
questions.answerA: Allows you time to react if another driver makes a mistake.
questions.answerB: Keeps you in a single area of the lane, limiting your movement.
questions.answerC: Allows you to rely on others to identify hazards.
questions.answerD: Requires you go faster to stay with traffic.
questions.explanation: Maintaining a cushion of space on all sides of your motorcycle helps to ensure that you have time and space to react if another road user makes a mistake.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a factor in determining blood alcohol content (BAC)?
questions.answerB: How fast the alcohol is consumed
questions.answerC: The drinker's body weight
questions.answerD: How often the drinker consumes alcohol
questions.explanation: The three major factors that affect a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) are the amount of alcohol consumed, how fast the alcohol was consumed, and the drinker's body weight. It is illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Protect your lane from other drivers.
questions.answerB: Allow you a nice view of scenery.
questions.answerC: Place you in other drivers’ blind spots.
questions.answerD: Hide your intentions from other drivers.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position can optimize a number of safety factors. Your lane position should keep you out of other vehicles’ blind spots, increase your ability to see and be seen, help you avoid surface hazards, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and provide you with an escape route from any hazards that might arise. You should be positioned in a way that discourages other drivers from trying to share your lane.

questions.question: When you are stopped, you:
questions.answerB: Should remain in neutral.
questions.answerC: Should remain in fifth gear.
questions.answerD: Can remain in any gear.
questions.explanation: Shift down through the gears with the clutch as you slow or stop. Remain in first gear while you are stopped so you can move quickly if needed.

questions.question: Which type of sign is yellow with black lettering or symbols?
questions.answerB: Service
questions.answerC: Regulatory
questions.answerD: Speed limit
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions.

questions.question: When slowing or stopping, you should use both brakes:
questions.answerA: Only if the pavement is wet.
questions.answerB: Infrequently.
questions.answerC: Only when riding in the city.
questions.answerD: Every time.
questions.explanation: You can achieve maximum stopping power by using both the front and rear brakes. You should use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: Which of the following is true?
questions.answerA: The front and rear brakes provide equal braking power.
questions.answerB: The front brake provides more braking power than the rear brake.
questions.answerC: The rear brake provides more braking power than the front brake.
questions.answerD: Only the front brake should be used when braking.
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear one, providing at least 70 percent of the total stopping power. Always use both brakes any time you slow or stop.

questions.question: The best source of information for your motorcycle is:
questions.answerB: A general book about motorcycles.
questions.answerC: Someone who has a different type of motorcycle.
questions.answerD: A television show about motorcycle riding.
questions.explanation: To be sure you are familiar with the specific type of motorcycle that you are planning to ride, read the owner's manual before riding it for the first time. This is particularly important if you are riding a borrowed motorcycle.

questions.question: When riding at night, a motorcyclist should maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerB: Three seconds.
questions.answerC: Four seconds.
questions.answerD: Five seconds.
questions.explanation: Because it is more difficult to see and judge distances in the dark than in daylight, you should maintain an expanded following distance of at least three seconds when riding at night. It may take you longer than usual to realize the vehicle in front of you has stopped and you may need additional time to slow or stop to avoid hitting the vehicle.

questions.question: The center portion of a lane:
questions.answerA: Is always the best part of the lane for a motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Often contains oil and grease, but is usually safe for riding.
questions.answerC: Often contains oil and grease, and is never safe for riding.
questions.answerD: Is the smoothest part of the lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars collect in a strip in the center of each lane. Unless the road is wet, this area still generally offers enough traction for motorcyclists to safely ride. You should still avoid riding on big buildups of oil and grease, often found at busy intersections or near toll booths.

questions.question: If carrying a load in a sidecar, the motorcycle's stopping distance:
questions.answerB: May be decreased.
questions.answerC: Is not a concern.
questions.answerD: Will be similar to the stopping distance of a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Because adding a load to a motorcycle increases its weight, the vehicle's inertia may increase, causing its stopping distance to increase. Begin slowing and stopping earlier when riding a motorcycle with a load or passenger in its sidecar.

questions.question: When being passed, do not move into the portion of the lane farthest from the passing vehicle because:
questions.answerA: The passing vehicle may re-enter your lane too early.
questions.answerB: You may prevent another vehicle from passing you.
questions.answerC: The portion of the lane nearest the passing vehicle is better.
questions.answerD: You are more likely to experience a wind blast from the passing vehicle on the far side of the lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed, you should not ride on the side of your lane that is farthest from the passing vehicle. Doing so may tempt the driver to return to your lane before there is actually room for them to do so safely.

questions.question: In general, riders should:
questions.answerA: Pick one lane position and always use it.
questions.answerB: Change lane positions frequently to prevent monotony.
questions.answerC: Choose a lane position that maximizes their space cushion.
questions.answerD: Never use the center lane position.
questions.explanation: Because road and traffic conditions are always changing, the safest lane position is also always changing. Choose the position that will maximize your space cushion and allow other drivers to see you most easily.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, a jacket should be worn:
questions.answerB: Only on cool days.
questions.answerC: Only on warm days.
questions.answerD: Only if the ride will be longer than half an hour.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should always wear a long-sleeved jacket when riding, even in warm weather when you may not think you need a jacket. It can help protect you against the sun and dehydration in hot weather.

questions.question: When is it important for a rider to use their mirrors?
questions.answerA: When slowing down or stopping suddenly
questions.answerB: When stopped at an intersection
questions.answerC: When changing lanes
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: It is particularly important for a rider to check their mirrors when slowing down or stopping, when stopped at an intersection, when changing lanes, and when turning.

questions.question: Impairment from drinking alcohol occurs:
questions.answerB: Once reaching the legal limit.
questions.answerC: Just above the legal limit.
questions.answerD: Well above the legal limit.
questions.explanation: It is never safe to operate a motorcycle after consuming any amount of alcohol. Impairment of the skills needed to safely ride begins well below the legal limit.

questions.question: The center portion of a lane usually contains an oily strip. This part of the lane is:
questions.answerB: Usually safe, unless the road is wet.
questions.answerC: Usually safe, unless it is sunny outside.
questions.answerD: Always safe, no matter the weather conditions.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars collect in a strip in the center of a traffic lane. Unless the road is wet, this area will generally still provide enough traction for motorcyclists to ride safely. Because the strip is usually no more than two feet wide, it is often possible to ride to one side of the strip and still be in the center portion of the lane.
